Kolumna Tanje Cegnar: Trajnostna mobilnost
Problem je preveč zapleten, da bi ga znali začeti učinkovito reševati.
03 Nov 2019, 12:15 by Tanja Cegnar
Ko sem pred tedni pripravljala ekskurzijo članov Slovenskega meteorološkega društva, sem najprej pomislila, da bi se na pot odpravili z javnim prevozom. A misel na to sem kmalu opustila, saj bi pot trajala predolgo, število razpoložljivih povezav pa je zelo skromno. Tako smo se na ogled meritev temperature, vlage, gibanja zraka, ogljikovega dioksida in radioaktivnosti v kraških jamah odpravili z osebnimi avtomobili, seveda pa smo poskrbeli, da so bili ti polno zasedeni. To ni bila moja prva izkušnja z javnim prevozom, ki mnogo manjših krajev le redko ali sploh ne povezuje, zato tamkajšnji prebivalci nimajo druge izbire kot avtomobil. V posebno neprijetnem položaju so nevozniki in tisti, ki avtomobila nimajo, saj so glede prevoza povsem odvisni od pomoči drugih.Vendar obstajajo tudi vzorne rešitve, vredne posnemanja. Prijetno sem bila presenečena, ko je bila na podelitvi priznanj do planeta Zemlja prijazna občina 2019 izpostavljena mestna občina Velenje, ki svojim prebivalcem ponuja brezplačen mestni prevoz in uporabo brezplačne izposoje koles. Gotovo je to prava smer načrtovanja trajnostne mestne mobilnosti, kjer je dobro poskrbljeno tudi za pešce. Tudi v marsikaterem drugem mestu, verjetno pa še najbolj v Ljubljani, bi tak pristop k reševanju mestnega prometa pomagal. Seveda morajo biti avtobusne proge prilagojene potrebam prebivalcev, prevoz pa dovolj pogost, da se odločajo za uporabo mestnega avtobusa. A tako bi rešili kar veliko problemov.
Problem je preveč zapleten, da bi ga znali začeti učinkovito reševati.
Zmanjšalo bi se onesnaženje zaradi prometa, ko se v prometnih konicah kolone avtomobilov le po polžje pomikajo po mestnih vpadnicah, posledično bi bil zrak manj onesnažen, ljudje bi porabili manj časa za volanom. Prispevali bi k zmanjšanju izpustov toplogrednih plinov pa tudi k bolj zdravemu okolju. Mar ta dva cilja nista vredna finančnega vložka, ki bi tako rešitev omogočil?Promet pogosto navajamo kot velikega onesnaževalca zraka, prispeva znaten delež izpustov toplogrednih plinov. Glavnino prispeva tranzitni promet čez Slovenijo; kolone tovornjakov na naših avtocestah, ki vozišča obremenjujejo veliko bolj kot osebni avtomobili. Že v prvih letih izpostavljanja prometa kot pomembnega vira toplogrednih plinov je bila izražena potreba po preusmeritvi tovornega cestnega prometa na železnico. A leta so tekla, spremenilo pa se ni prav veliko, saj pri velikih infrastrukturnih projektih pogosto bolj stopicamo na mestu kot napredujemo.Statistika kaže, da se število prepeljanih potnikov z vlaki povečuje. To je spodbudna vest, a pot iz Ljubljane v Budimpešto, na Dunaj ali v Trst še vedno traja dolgo, predolgo, ker naše proge ne zmorejo velikih hitrosti.


FOTO: Guliver/Getty Images

Trajnostna mobilnost je in bo še kar dolgo ostala velik problem in izziv, v razpravi, kako ga reševati, se bodo še dolgo kresale iskre. A reševanje trajnostne mobilnosti je le kamenček v mozaiku podnebnih sprememb, s katerimi se vsa svetovna javnost dokaj neuspešno sooča že desetletja. Opozorila znanstvenikov in priznanih inštitutov ter pozivi nevladnih organizacij niso vodila k učinkovitemu ukrepanju politikov. Vse bolj sem prepričana, da ne zato, ker jim ne bi bilo mar, ampak ker je problem preveč zapleten, da bi ga znali začeti učinkovito reševati.Nasveti in predlogi ozko usmerjenih znanstvenikov niso dovolj za uspešno ukrepanje, ker kaj hitro trčijo ob druge interese in vrednote, ki se zdijo v sodobni družbi velik dosežek, ki ga je treba skrbno varovati. Vprašanj, ki bi si jih morali zastaviti v povezavi z okoljem in podnebnimi spremembami, je veliko. Ko so znanstveniki opozorili na problem ozonske luknje, je mednarodna skupnost hitro in učinkovito ukrepala, ker je bila tehnologija za rešitev problema poznana in izvedljiva brez večjega vpliva na sodobni življenjski slog.

Tanja Cegnar's column: Sustainable mobility
The problem is too complicated to know how to begin to solve it effectively.
03 Nov 2019, 11:15 by Tanja Cegnar
When I was preparing an excursion for the members of the Slovenian Meteorological Society a few weeks ago, I first thought that we would take the public transport route. But I soon abandoned the idea, as the journey would take too long, and the number of available connections is very modest. So we went with cars to take measurements of temperature, humidity, air movement, carbon dioxide and radioactivity in Karst caves, but of course we made sure that they were fully occupied. This was not my first experience with public transport, which rarely or never connects many smaller towns, so the local people have no choice but to have a car. Particularly embarrassing are the non-drivers and those who do not have a car, as they are completely dependent on the assistance of others for transportation. I was pleasantly surprised when the City of Velenje was honored at the 2019 awards ceremony for the planet Earth-friendly Municipality, which offers its residents free urban transportation and the use of free bike rentals. Certainly this is the right direction for sustainable urban mobility planning, where pedestrians are well taken care of. In many other cities, and probably even the most in Ljubljana, such an approach to solving urban traffic would help. Of course, bus routes need to be tailored to the needs of residents, and transportation is frequent enough to decide to use a city bus. But that would solve a lot of problems.
The problem is too complicated to know how to begin to solve it effectively.
Traffic pollution would be reduced when, at the peak of the car, the columns of cars just wander through the city roads, as a result, the air would be less polluted and people would spend less time behind the wheel. We would contribute to reducing greenhouse gas emissions as well as a healthier environment. Are these two goals not worth the financial contribution that would make such a solution? Transport is often cited as a major air pollutant, contributing a significant share of greenhouse gas emissions. The bulk is due to transit traffic through Slovenia; truck columns on our highways that load the carriageways much more than passenger cars. Even in the first years of exposure to transport as an important source of greenhouse gases, the need to shift freight road transport to rail was expressed. But the years have gone by, but not much has changed, as large infrastructure projects often stop at a place more than we make progress. Statistics show that the number of passengers carried by train is increasing. This is encouraging news, but the route from Ljubljana to Budapest, Vienna or Trieste still takes a long, long time because our routes are not capable of high speeds.


PHOTO: Gulliver / Getty Images

Sustainable mobility is, and will continue to be, a major problem and challenge for a long time, and the debate on how to tackle it will continue to spark sparks. But tackling sustainable mobility is just a touchstone in the mosaic of climate change that has been unsuccessfully faced by the entire global public for decades. The warnings of scientists and renowned institutes and the calls of NGOs did not lead to effective action by politicians. I'm increasingly convinced that not because they don't care, but because the problem is too complex to be able to effectively solve it. and values that seem to be a great achievement in modern society that must be carefully guarded. There are many questions that we should ask ourselves in relation to the environment and climate change. When scientists pointed to the problem of the ozone hole, the international community acted swiftly and efficiently because the technology to solve the problem was known and feasible without significantly affecting the modern lifestyle.
